question: 3 (b)
sols_html:
Using the change of variable

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle x = 2\tan(\theta)\end{aligned}\]

and taking a derivative with respect to x on both sides we obtain

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle 1 = 2\sec^2(\theta) \frac{d\theta}{dx}\end{aligned}\]

and since \(1+\tan^2(\theta) = \sec^2(\theta)\) we have

\[\begin{aligned} (4+x^2)^{3/2} &= (4+4\tan^2(\theta))^{3/2}\\ &= 4^{3/2} (1+\tan^2(\theta))^{3/2}\\ &= 8 (\sec^2(\theta))^{3/2}\\ &= 8 \sec^3(\theta)\end{aligned}\]

and so our integral becomes

\[\begin{aligned} \int \frac{1}{(4+x^2)^{3/2}}\,dx &= \int \frac{1}{8 \sec^3(\theta)} 2\sec^2(\theta) \,d\theta\\ &= \int \frac{1}{4 \sec(\theta)} \,d\theta\\ &=\frac{1}{4} \int \cos(\theta) \,d\theta\\ &= \frac{1}{4} \sin(\theta) + c\end{aligned}\]

Now using that

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{x}{2} = \tan(\theta) = \frac{\sin(\theta)}{\cos(\theta)}\end{aligned}\]

we get that

\[\begin{aligned} \cos(\theta) = \frac{2\sin(\theta)}{x}\end{aligned}\]

and since \(\sin^2(\theta) + \cos^2(\theta) = 1\) we have that

\[\begin{aligned} \sin^2(\theta) + \frac{4\sin^2(\theta)}{x^2} = 1 \quad\text{so}\quad \sin^2(\theta)(1+\frac{4}{x^2}) = 1\end{aligned}\]

and so finally we can solve for \(\sin(\theta)\) and get

\[\begin{aligned} \sin(\theta) = \frac{x}{\sqrt{4 + x^2}}\end{aligned}\]

which we can now plug back into our integral and conclude that

\[\begin{aligned} \int \frac{1}{(4+x^2)^{3/2}} \,dx = \frac{x}{4\sqrt{4 + x^2}} + c\end{aligned}\]
